quizSrc.term: Which of the following defines the AI black box problem?A. A dangerous machine intelligence put in a digital prisonB. Machine intelligence making something illusory, like pulling a rabbit from a hatC. The challenge of understanding the inner workings of opaque systemsD. Not being able to know how something crashed or failed
quizSrc.definition: C. The challenge of understanding the inner workings of opaque systems

quizSrc.term: Which of the following elements are important aspects of ethical integrity with regards to data? (Select two.)A. If the holders of data are trustworthy entities.B. If the data is commercially viable or monetarily valuable.C. Whether the data was gathered in an ethical manner.D. What type of data (audio, visual, etc.) is being collected and/or utilized.
quizSrc.definition: A. If the holders of data are trustworthy entities.  C. Whether the data was gathered in an ethical manner.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following best describes why data is sometimes compared to oil? (Select two.)A. Data can be monetarily valuable.B. Data can damage the environment.C. Data can be easily monopolized.D. Data can fuel algorithmic technologies.
quizSrc.definition: A. Data can be monetarily valuable.  D. Data can fuel algorithmic technologies.

quizSrc.term: At what point should ethical consideration ideally be applied to emerging technologies?A. Upon delivery, with appropriate warranties where necessary.B. During periodic reviews, with ongoing customer feedback solicited.C. From its inception, through maintenance, to applying foresight regarding its decommissioning.D. Once an ethical issue has received negative feedback in public media.
quizSrc.definition: C. From its inception, through maintenance, to applying foresight regarding its decommissioning.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following describes dual-use or multipurpose data?A. Data that can be easily shared with a partner or family member for mutual enjoyment.B. Data that can be used in multiple devices or formats, such as a video on a Smart TV, tablet, and computer.C. Data collected for one application that could also be applied to another application in a different domain.D. Data that can be transformed into multiple forms, e.g. extracting audio from a video file.
quizSrc.definition: C. Data collected for one application that could also be applied to another application in a different domain.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are important ethical elements to safeguard within ethical AI systems? (Select two.)A. Accountability and management of bias.B. Transparency and explainability, balanced with privacy.C. The number of layers, tensors, or parameters used in a model.D. Performance and optimization.
quizSrc.definition: A. Accountability and management of bias.  B. Transparency and explainability, balanced with privacy.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is the generally agreed upon current state of the art of AI?A. SuperintelligenceB. Narrow AIC. Strong AID. Perceptrons
quizSrc.definition: B. Narrow AI

quizSrc.term: Which of the following describe important aspects of why emerging technologies are so capable and powerful? (Select two.)A. They can automate very complex operations.B. They may be able to self-improve by learning from data.C. They are exciting and captivating to many people.D. They can displace workers by performing their jobs more efficiently.
quizSrc.definition: A. They can automate very complex operations.  B. They may be able to self-improve by learning from data.

quizSrc.term: Management asks someone to do a data-related task. Which of the following would likely be ethically problematic? (Select two.)A. Aggregate data together.B. Change data to another format.C. Manipulate data or alter its interpretation.D. Delete any erroneous data.
quizSrc.definition: C. Manipulate data or alter its interpretation.  D. Delete any erroneous data.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following describe important aspects in the role of an ethical AI engineer? (Select two.)A. Building and maintaining computational hardware.B. Writing new equations to express intelligence.C. Keeping up with the latest developments and vulnerabilities.D. Cleaning and sorting data, and auditing for bias.
quizSrc.definition: C. Keeping up with the latest developments and vulnerabilities.  D. Cleaning and sorting data, and auditing for bias.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following, by itself, qualifies as personally identifiable information (PII)?A. Temperature readings for an office buildingB. A user's customer ID in an online ordering systemC. System events added to a logD. A user's home address
quizSrc.definition: D. A user's home address

quizSrc.term: Why are groups like race and religion considered protected classes?A. These groups have been used as the basis for wholesale discrimination.B. These groups can be used to personally identify someone.C. People use these groups as the basis for their identities.D. Organizations are legally not allowed to collect information about these groups.
quizSrc.definition: A. These groups have been used as the basis for wholesale discrimination.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following describes an opt-out policy in regards to the collection of private data?A. Data about the user is always collected, regardless of the user's consent.B. Data about that user isn't collected until that user explicitly states you are allowed to.C. Data about the user is never collected, regardless of the user's consent.D. Data about the user is automatically collected unless that user explicitly states that you should not do so.
quizSrc.definition: D. Data about the user is automatically collected unless that user explicitly states that you should not do so.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are key principles of privacy by design? (Select two.)A. Organizations must incorporate privacy protections throughout the project lifecycle.B. Organizations must keep the focus of privacy protections on the business rather than the user.C. Organizations must not expose the operational practices and technologies used to protect user privacy.D. Organizations must be proactive in protecting against privacy risks, not reactive.
quizSrc.definition: A. Organizations must incorporate privacy protections throughout the project lifecycle.  D. Organizations must be proactive in protecting against privacy risks, not reactive.

quizSrc.term: What is the purpose of differential privacy?A. To only allow certain parties to access certain portions of the data.B. To enable parties to share private data without revealing individuals represented in the data.C. To remove the direct identifiers that can be used to identify individuals.D. To ensure the data is completely confidential and cannot be read by unauthorized parties.
quizSrc.definition: B. To enable parties to share private data without revealing individuals represented in the data.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following describes the concept of liability?A. Answering for one's actions to an authority figure.B. Taking ownership of an assigned task.C. The legal responsibility for one's actions.D. The moral duty one has to take action.
quizSrc.definition: C. The legal responsibility for one's actions.

quizSrc.term: What does it mean to call a click-through agreement a "contract of adhesion"? | Both parties are legally bound by the agreement. | Both parties are equally responsible for ensuring the agreement is adhered to. | One party is forced into a "take-it-or-leave-it" situation. | One party is forced into using the service after agreeing.
quizSrc.definition: One party is forced into a "take-it-or-leave-it" situation.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is a type of technology contract that establishes the goals of both parties and describes how those goals will be achieved?A. Software as a Service (SaaS)B. Service-level agreement (SLA)C. Terms of Service (ToS)D. End-user license agreement (EULA)
quizSrc.definition: B. Service-level agreement (SLA)

quizSrc.term: How does a smart contract differ from a traditional contract?A. Smart contracts eliminate the need for a central authority.B. Smart contracts guarantee that all parties are anonymous.C. Smart contracts serve a different purpose than traditional contracts.D. Smart contracts are more effective than traditional contracts.
quizSrc.definition: A. Smart contracts eliminate the need for a central authority.

quizSrc.term: How can a visual contract be easier to understand than a written contract?A. The use of pictures is more accessible to all people, whereas a written contract may be difficult for someone with a reading disability to understand.B. The use of pictures without any text makes it easier for most people to comprehend the details of a contract.C. The use of pictures with simple text makes it easier for the layperson to understand the details of a contract.D. The use of pictures explains the contract in greater detail than a written contract, making it easier for anyone to understand the particulars.
quizSrc.definition: C. The use of pictures with simple text makes it easier for the layperson to understand the details of a contract.

quizSrc.term: What causes bias?A. Biases are caused by the opinions of our families.B. Bias is biological, we are born with it.C. Bias is caused by the media.D. Biases are learned from our families, our social groups, and the media.
quizSrc.definition: D. Biases are learned from our families, our social groups, and the media.

quizSrc.term: What is the fundamental attribution error?A. When you believe your chances of experiencing something negative are lower and your chances of experiencing something positive are higher than others.B. When you believe your ideas are normal and that the majority of people agree with you.C. When you say your bad behavior is caused by the situation, but when other people display the same bad behavior, it is caused by a personality trait.D. When you incorrectly assume a cause and effect relationship for two correlated variables.
quizSrc.definition: C. When you say your bad behavior is caused by the situation, but when other people display the same bad behavior, it is caused by a personality trait.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are actions that can help combat implicit bias? (Select three.)A. Interacting with diverse groups of people.B. Surrounding yourself with others who have similar experiences.C. Cultivating awareness of your own biases.D. Exposing yourself to "counter-stereotypical" examples.E. Obtaining your information from the same one or two media sources that your family and friends access.
quizSrc.definition: A. Interacting with diverse groups of people.  C. Cultivating awareness of your own biases.  D. Exposing yourself to "counter-stereotypical" examples.

quizSrc.term: When conducting an opinion poll, which of the following biases do you need to guard against the most when collecting your data?A. Correlation biasB. Modeling biasC. Misclassification biasD. Sampling bias
quizSrc.definition: D. Sampling bias

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is an example of a cognitive bias?A. Correlation biasB. Modeling biasC. Misclassification biasD. Anchoring bias
quizSrc.definition: D. Anchoring bias

quizSrc.term: Are criminal justice risk assessments race-neutral?A. No, the data is biased as it reflects historical bias.B. Yes, technology in itself is not racist.C. Yes, algorithms replace human judgement and they are unbiased.D. No, it is designed with intention to be unfair.
quizSrc.definition: A. No, the data is biased as it reflects historical bias.

quizSrc.term: Which type of bias causes people to trust an automated decision-making system (ADS) over a human's decision? | Complacency bias | Automation bias | Confirmation bias | Implicit bias
quizSrc.definition: Automation bias

quizSrc.term: How can confirmation bias impact us socially? (Select two.)A. It can prevent us from being social with other people.B. It can impede socio-political cooperation.C. It can lead to a diverse set of friends.D. It can lead to groupthink, which can in turn halt forward progress.
quizSrc.definition: B. It can impede socio-political cooperation.  D. It can lead to groupthink, which can in turn halt forward progress.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following describes an illusory-correlation bias?A. When you incorrectly assume a correlation because there is an illusory confounding variable.B. When you correlate variables that do not exist in your data set.C. When you correlate a variable with a confounding variable.D. When you incorrectly assume a cause and effect relationship because two variables are correlated.
quizSrc.definition: A. When you incorrectly assume a correlation because there is an illusory confounding variable.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is one explanation for why cognitive biases exist?A. We use them to help remember things.B. We receive too much information and are overloaded.C. They are taught to us in school.D. They help us think logically instead of emotionally.
quizSrc.definition: B. We receive too much information and are overloaded.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is a formative ethics theory that states that maximizing happiness is the primary standard for determining what is right or wrong?A. Categorical imperativeB. UtilitarianismC. DeontologyD. Virtue ethics
quizSrc.definition: B. Utilitarianism

quizSrc.term: Which of the following statements are promoted by the categorical imperative? (Select three.)A. Act in such a way that your actions may become a universal law.B. You have a moral duty to choose your actions based on their potential outcomes.C. Each person must use reason to will moral laws.D. Don't treat people as a means to an end; treat them always as an end.
quizSrc.definition: A. Act in such a way that your actions may become a universal law.  C. Each person must use reason to will moral laws.  D. Don't treat people as a means to an end; treat them always as an end.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following statements accurately describes the philosophical concept of predeterminism?A. All events, past, present, and future, are determined in advance.B. All future events are determined by preceding events, as in a chain, but human beings may still be able to interfere with this chain of events.C. Human beings are able to make choices whose outcomes are not already determined.D. All events are predestined to happen by a supernatural force.
quizSrc.definition: A. All events, past, present, and future, are determined in advance.

quizSrc.term: How do norms differ from morals?A. Morals involve value judgments; norms do not.B. Norms are universal to all cultures; morals are not.C. Norms form the basis for morals.D. Morals are collective; norms are more personal.
quizSrc.definition: A. Morals involve value judgments; norms do not.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are consequences of saying that someone or something has moral agency? (Select two.)A. The moral agent is capable of determining right and wrong.B. The moral agent can be held responsible for their actions.C. The moral agent acts in a morally correct manner.D. The moral agent follows a deontological code of ethics.
quizSrc.definition: A. The moral agent is capable of determining right and wrong.  B. The moral agent can be held responsible for their actions.

quizSrc.term: Why is deciding how to act using moral reasoning not always a feasible goal for human beings?A. Most people are not educated on normative ethical theories and therefore cannot perform true moral reasoning.B. Moral reasoning is too complicated to apply to a real-world situation.C. Moral reasoning has few tangible benefits for most people.D. Human decision making is often influenced by emotion and not logic.
quizSrc.definition: D. Human decision making is often influenced by emotion and not logic.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following statements are true regarding the purpose of moral psychology? (Select two.)A. Moral psychology seeks to understand why people act morally or immorally.B. Moral psychology seeks to understand how the human mind develops morality.C. Moral psychology seeks to understand the nature of what it means to be moral.D. Moral psychology seeks to understand what the best way to act morally is.
quizSrc.definition: A. Moral psychology seeks to understand why people act morally or immorally.  B. Moral psychology seeks to understand how the human mind develops morality.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is an example of applied ethics?A. Professional ethicsB. Moral relativismC. Virtue ethicsD. Pluralism
quizSrc.definition: A. Professional ethics

quizSrc.term: Your organization has developed an AI system that recommends treatments for hospital patients. Some questions have been raised about the ethics of how these treatments are determined. What applied ethics domain do these concerns fall under?A. Environmental ethicsB. Business ethicsC. BioethicsD. Engineering ethics
quizSrc.definition: C. Bioethics

quizSrc.term: What does it mean to say that human rights are inalienable? (Select two.)A. Inalienable rights are inherent in all human beings.B. Inalienable rights cannot be taken away except in extreme circumstances.C. Inalienable rights are conditional.D. Inalienable rights are derived from tradition.
quizSrc.definition: A. Inalienable rights are inherent in all human beings.  B. Inalienable rights cannot be taken away except in extreme circumstances.

quizSrc.term: What does "ethics by design" mean? | A creative design approach as the focus for ethics. | A reference to the framework set forth by IEEE's Ethically Aligned Design. | An approach in which ethics is considered from the initial design stage. | A reference to one of the tenets of engineering activism.
quizSrc.definition: An approach in which ethics is considered from the initial design stage.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following describes why explainability is important?A. It is necessary so that internal stakeholders can understand how a system works.B. It provides accountability and trust.C. It provides interpretations of a system's actions.D. It enables you to explain a system for shareholder purposes.
quizSrc.definition: B. It provides accountability and trust.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following describes personhood?A. Personhood is often used to dictate how something is treated.B. Personhood is a concept that applies to narrow AI.C. Personhood is the legal protection provided to AI systems.D. Personhood is an individual's right to freedom.
quizSrc.definition: A. Personhood is often used to dictate how something is treated.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following describe how adopting ethical practices can be a strategic differentiator? (Select three.)A. It will encourage applicants to apply for your company.B. It will ensure you comply with regulations.C. It will support the development of strategic partnerships.D. It will reduce your business obligations toward customers and business partners.E. It will build customer trust.
quizSrc.definition: A. It will encourage applicants to apply for your company.  C. It will support the development of strategic partnerships.  E. It will build customer trust.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following best describes beneficence?A. Beneficence is a term coined by IBM that relates to their Green Horizons initiative in 2014.B. Beneficence is the promotion of efficient systems that perform rapidly and benefit companies.C. Beneficence is the promotion of well-being for moral agents like humans.D. Beneficence is the promotion of well-being, not just for moral agents like humans, but of animals, the environment, and societies.
quizSrc.definition: D. Beneficence is the promotion of well-being, not just for moral agents like humans, but of animals, the environment, and societies.

quizSrc.term: What is the difference between beneficence and non-maleficence?A. Beneficence refers to "do only good" and non-maleficence refers to "do no harm."B. Non-maleficence refers only to malevolent artificial general intelligence (AGI), while beneficence can refer to any "good" emerging technology.C. Beneficence is a less important goal for the field of AI than non-maleficence.D. Beneficence and non-maleficence are quite similar and often interchangeable.
quizSrc.definition: A. Beneficence refers to "do only good" and non-maleficence refers to "do no harm."

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are valid concerns regarding electronic personalities? (Select two.)A. That they would create unfair advantages, as not everyone has access to the same rights.B. That individuals would start applying for electronic personalities.C. That they will make it more difficult to access information.D. That they would absolve manufacturers of liability.
quizSrc.definition: A. That they would create unfair advantages, as not everyone has access to the same rights.  D. That they would absolve manufacturers of liability.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are ways to participate in engineering activism? (Select two.)A. Follow a code of ethics.B. Perform all tasks required of you.C. Engage with the public.D. Follow ethics by design.
quizSrc.definition: A. Follow a code of ethics.  C. Engage with the public.

quizSrc.term: How can AI uphold justice?A. The more AI-based products being used in the justice system, the more justice can be upheld.B. AI systems can be designed from the start to help promote fairness and minimize bias.C. AI systems can replace human judges, who are often biased.D. AI can automate many of the clerical tasks involved in the justice system.
quizSrc.definition: B. AI systems can be designed from the start to help promote fairness and minimize bias.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are examples of how AI can limit human autonomy? (Select two.)A. Weapon systems can limit human autonomy as humans may not have decision-making capability or understand the decision making.B. AI systems might impact certain vulnerable groups such as the elderly and children differently than the rest of the population, which could limit those groups' autonomy.C. AI systems can assist individuals with automated, repetitive, or dangerous tasks.D. AI systems can perform tasks that humans cannot, such as processing millions of data records in a matter of seconds.
quizSrc.definition: A. Weapon systems can limit human autonomy as humans may not have decision-making capability or understand the decision making.  B. AI systems might impact certain vulnerable groups such as the elderly and children differently than the rest of the population, which could limit those groups' autonomy.

quizSrc.term: Which school of philosophical thought primarily advocates for the greatest good for the greatest amount of people?A. Kantian ethicsB. UtilitarianismC. DeontologyD. Virtue ethics
quizSrc.definition: B. Utilitarianism

quizSrc.term: Which type of entity are the OECD Principles on Artificial Intelligence mostly geared towards?A. Municipal governmentsB. Private corporationsC. National governmentsD. Individuals
quizSrc.definition: C. National governments

quizSrc.term: Which of the following principles are most commonly cited in AI-based ethical frameworks?A. Happiness and spiritual contentmentB. Human control and autonomyC. Fairness and non-discriminationD. Transparency and explainability
quizSrc.definition: D. Transparency and explainability

quizSrc.term: Which of the following frameworks primarily promotes human rights?A. The Montreal DeclarationB. The Asilomar AI PrinciplesC. The Toronto DeclarationD. The Beijing AI Principles
quizSrc.definition: C. The Toronto Declaration

quizSrc.term: Which of the following best describes capability caution as referenced in the Asilomar AI Principles?A. Should there be a greater reliance on AI, measures should be taken to ensure that humans are still capable of finding work.B. We should keep limits on on what artificial general intelligence (AGI) is capable of.C. If there is no understanding of the internal mechanisms of AI, then AI development should be halted.D. Given a lack of consensus, we should avoid strong assumptions regarding upper limits on future AI capabilities.
quizSrc.definition: D. Given a lack of consensus, we should avoid strong assumptions regarding upper limits on future AI capabilities.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following describes the principle of transparency in the context of AI systems?A. Transparency enables human observers to reproduce the decision-making process of an AI system.B. Transparency enables human observers to see inside the decision-making process of an AI system.C. Transparency enables human observers to tweak the decision-making process of an AI system.D. Transparency enables human observers to understand the decision-making process of an AI system.
quizSrc.definition: B. Transparency enables human observers to see inside the decision-making process of an AI system.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is a case study that best represents the principle of professional responsibility?A. The Asilomar AI Principles' definition of capability cautionB. The American Medical Association's definition of AI as augmented intelligenceC. The Beijing AI Principles' tenets about the use of AID. The IEEE Ethically Aligned Design's discussion on classical ethics
quizSrc.definition: B. The American Medical Association's definition of AI as augmented intelligence

quizSrc.term: If you are attempting to build a new framework for the research and development (R&D) of AI, which of the following frameworks might you look at first for its emphasis in this area?A. The G20 AI PrinciplesB. The Montreal Declaration for a Responsible Development of Artificial IntelligenceC. The American Medical Association's definition of artificial intelligenceD. The Beijing AI Principles
quizSrc.definition: D. The Beijing AI Principles

quizSrc.term: In AI, the principle of privacy is most commonly referred to in the context of which of the following concepts?A. TransparencyB. Data protectionC. Human controlD. Personal protection
quizSrc.definition: B. Data protection

quizSrc.term: Which of the following describes an ethical framework?A. Ethical frameworks apply meta-ethical theories to everyday business operations.B. Ethical frameworks consolidate regulatory requirements for an industry.C. Ethical frameworks raise timeless ethical questions that are not easily put into action.D. Ethical frameworks seek to mitigate ethical concerns by creating actionable steps.
quizSrc.definition: D. Ethical frameworks seek to mitigate ethical concerns by creating actionable steps.

quizSrc.term: Why does the trolley problem pose an ethical predicament?A. The moral responsibility is split between you and the person controlling the trolley.B. You have to make a choice between two scenarios where choosing one leads to loss of life in the other.C. You as the actor don't have sufficient control over the circumstance.D. There are so many potential outcomes that it becomes difficult to choose one that is most ethical.
quizSrc.definition: B. You have to make a choice between two scenarios where choosing one leads to loss of life in the other.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following ethical considerations should have priority in an emergency situation like the use of contact-tracing solutions during a pandemic? (Select two.)A. PrivacyB. BiasC. ExplainabilityD. Accountability
quizSrc.definition: A. Privacy  D. Accountability

quizSrc.term: In using AI-enabled solutions within the context of medical imaging analysis, which of the following is the most important ethical consideration?A. ExplainabilityB. PrivacyC. SecurityD. Bias
quizSrc.definition: A. Explainability

quizSrc.term: If an AI-enabled system enables addictive behavior, which of the following makes for the most compelling argument to stop development work on that system?A. The user will share more data with the system because of increased use.B. There is a lack of accountability on the part of the user since they overuse the service.C. The process for obtaining consent has not been made transparent to the user.D. The system, as designed, acts counter to the well-being of the users.
quizSrc.definition: D. The system, as designed, acts counter to the well-being of the users.

quizSrc.term: Why do smart toys raise additional ethical concerns over those that are raised in the course of other products and services that use AI?A. Children are more susceptible to manipulation and therefore need extra protective measures.B. The smart toys store personal data on the device, which can be stolen.C. It is difficult to obtain informed consent for the use of the smart toy.D. They are used in the privacy of homes rather than in public settings, like other products or services.
quizSrc.definition: A. Children are more susceptible to manipulation and therefore need extra protective measures.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following software development principles is essential in the real-world deployment of AI-enabled software applications in critical scenarios like self-driving cars?A. Robustness to adversarial examplesB. Continuous integration and deployment of patch updatesC. Version control of the AI models deployedD. Architectural design analysis
quizSrc.definition: A. Robustness to adversarial examples

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is the most important argument in favor of content moderation in online platforms?A. It prevents the spread of disinformation that can cause harm to vulnerable populations.B. It helps uphold freedom of expression for everyone and doesn't give anyone special rights.C. It creates adequate incentives for everyone to share their opinions.D. It prevents the development of monopolies in terms of content creators.
quizSrc.definition: A. It prevents the spread of disinformation that can cause harm to vulnerable populations.

quizSrc.term: Why is the question of robot rights and emancipation one that isn't as important as addressing issues of bias, privacy, transparency, and other principles discussed in the various ethical frameworks? | Robots are mechanical instruments and therefore don't deserve to have rights. | There is no legal precedent for granting rights to entities that are not humans. | Humans are anthropocentric and don't want to extend rights to other sentient entities. | These rights necessitate that robots become sentient entities, which is currently not feasible.
quizSrc.definition: These rights necessitate that robots become sentient entities, which is currently not feasible.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is the most important ethical consideration regarding technical developments like deepfakes?A. They take away monetization opportunities, leaving individuals unfairly compensated for their data.B. They are built on technological progress made by a third-party organization.C. They violate data sharing agreements in many jurisdictions.D. They usurp a person's likeness and can then be weaponized against them.
quizSrc.definition: D. They usurp a person's likeness and can then be weaponized against them.

quizSrc.term: Why are anonymization and pseudonymization insufficient protection measures against breaches of data privacy and security?A. They don't integrate well into data science and machine learning workflows.B. They only work in scenarios with particular kinds of personal information.C. They destroy the usefulness of the data.D. They can be broken by combining this data with other publicly available data.
quizSrc.definition: D. They can be broken by combining this data with other publicly available data.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are ways that regulations differ from ethical frameworks? (Select two.)A. Regulations provide a clear basis for potential litigation.B. Regulations have legal enforcement behind them.C. Regulations are flexible in their implementation.D. Regulations are often industry led.
quizSrc.definition: A. Regulations provide a clear basis for potential litigation.  B. Regulations have legal enforcement behind them.

quizSrc.term: Your business handles the personal data of California residents. Which of the following regulations would enable a resident to request that their data be deleted from your company's files? | CCPA | PCI DSS | OECD Privacy Guidelines | COPPA
quizSrc.definition: CCPA

quizSrc.term: Which of the following does the Brazilian General Data Protection Act (LGPD) mandate? (Select two.)A. Data protection auditsB. Data protection analystsC. Data protection officersD. Data protection impact assessments
quizSrc.definition: C. Data protection officers  D. Data protection impact assessments

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is a standard or regulation that focuses on ensuring the implementation of strong cybersecurity techniques like network security and cryptography to protect data?A. PCI DSSB. PIPEDAC. POPID. FERPA
quizSrc.definition: A. PCI DSS

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are requirements set forth by the Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA)? (Select two.)A. Organizations must obtain consent from individuals regarding the collection and use of biometric data.B. Organizations must store biometric data in local, on-premises databases.C. Organizations must destroy biometric data in a timely fashion.D. Organizations must not transmit biometric data across an unsecured network like the Internet.
quizSrc.definition: A. Organizations must obtain consent from individuals regarding the collection and use of biometric data.  C. Organizations must destroy biometric data in a timely fashion.

quizSrc.term: The Children's Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA) safeguards the privacy of which age group's personal information? | Anyone under 13 years old | Anyone under 18 years old | Anyone between 13 and 18 years old | Anyone between 5 and 13 years old
quizSrc.definition: Anyone under 13 years old

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are advantages to adopting standards frameworks like ISO 27000? (Select two.)A. Formal certification processes that provide competitive advantageB. Regulatory weight and legal enforcementC. Technology-specific focus and precise implementation instructionsD. International support, recognition, and involvement
quizSrc.definition: A. Formal certification processes that provide competitive advantage  D. International support, recognition, and involvement

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is a notable aspect of the Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act (PIPEDA) when compared to similar laws and regulations?A. Its exclusive focus on a single domain rather than a breadth of domainsB. Its nationwide scope and specific national focusC. A stipulation to continue providing service even if data usage is deniedD. The early date of its inauguration
quizSrc.definition: C. A stipulation to continue providing service even if data usage is denied

quizSrc.term: Which of the following resources does the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) provide to organizations?A. Industrial configurationsB. Measurement technologiesC. Reference materialsD. Security tools
quizSrc.definition: C. Reference materials

quizSrc.term: Which of the following ethical domains does the IEEE 7000 series explore? (Select two.)A. Machine-readable privacy termsB. Fair competitionC. Emulated empathyD. Personnel safety
quizSrc.definition: A. Machine-readable privacy terms  C. Emulated empathy

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are important elements of the data minimization principle? (Select two.)A. Only delete data that can be easily replacedB. Only collect data that is strictly necessaryC. Only compress data that needs to be kept as small as possibleD. Only keep data for as long as it is needed
quizSrc.definition: B. Only collect data that is strictly necessary  D. Only keep data for as long as it is needed

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are logical arguments in favor of an organization maintaining compliance? (Select two.)A. Long-term cost savings due to avoiding finesB. Reduced time to deploymentC. Reduced costs of developmentD. Avoidance of reputational damage
quizSrc.definition: A. Long-term cost savings due to avoiding fines  D. Avoidance of reputational damage

quizSrc.term: How does increasing AI performance often conflict with the desire for explainability?A. Increasing AI performance sometimes reduces the transparency of input data used in training, making it more difficult to explain decision-making processes.B. Increasing AI performance sometimes leads to certain evaluation metrics no longer being useful, making it more difficult to explain decision-making processes.C. Increasing AI performance sometimes leads to greater model complexity, making it more difficult to explain decision-making processes.D. Increasing AI performance sometimes removes human-in-the-loop (HITL) methods, making it more difficult to explain decision-making processes.
quizSrc.definition: C. Increasing AI performance sometimes leads to greater model complexity, making it more difficult to explain decision-making processes.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following explains why efficiency can sometimes incur systemic fragility?A. High-efficiency machines often require more maintenanceB. Increased efficiency tends to compound over timeC. Efficiency benefits may lead to complex second-order costsD. Increased efficiency tends to create cost savings
quizSrc.definition: C. Efficiency benefits may lead to complex second-order costs

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are possible benefits of a human-in-the-loop (HITL) architecture? (Select two.)A. Improving the speed of autonomous decision makingB. Eliminating the potential for human error in decision makingC. Balancing the negative effects of an AI system on people with the effects on environments and objectsD. Mitigating excessive scope or potential collateral damage
quizSrc.definition: C. Balancing the negative effects of an AI system on people with the effects on environments and objects  D. Mitigating excessive scope or potential collateral damage

quizSrc.term: How does the "virtuous cycle" that benefits Big Tech operate? | Better classes of customers lead to richer and more refined data for algorithmic systems. | Data-driven algorithms improve solutions, leading to new customers, and better data. | Organizations write algorithms with fewer biases, which leads to fairer outcomes. | By acting virtuous, the public respects Big Tech more and more.
quizSrc.definition: Better classes of customers lead to richer and more refined data for algorithmic systems. | Data-driven algorithms improve solutions, leading to new customers, and better data.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is often in opposition to moral relativism?A. Customs and conventionsB. Evidence-based policyC. Subjective perspectivesD. Cultural mores
quizSrc.definition: B. Evidence-based policy

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are important aspects of resolving complex and confounding business pressures? (Select two.)A. Managing expectations that not everyone can get what they want, when they want itB. Prioritizing ethical and safety concerns over business desires in all cases and situationsC. Assuring everyone that their desires can be accommodated without compromiseD. Engaging with multiple stakeholders to understand their particular needs
quizSrc.definition: A. Managing expectations that not everyone can get what they want, when they want it  D. Engaging with multiple stakeholders to understand their particular needs

quizSrc.term: You plan on streamlining your company's product experience, but you also want to uphold the agency and autonomy of your users. Which of the following actions would uphold these principles? (Select two.) | Refraining from guiding users into something they didn't wish for or intend | Applying machine intelligence to simulate customer behavior | Respecting the right of the user to choose and customize their experiences | Enabling government agencies to have a personalized interface with software
quizSrc.definition: Refraining from guiding users into something they didn't wish for or intend | Respecting the right of the user to choose and customize their experiences

quizSrc.term: Which of the following describe corporate hegemony? (Select two.)A. Consolidating interests through mergers and acquisitionsB. Locking out smaller players, leading to monopolies or cartelsC. Spending large sums on corporate branding and marketingD. Making multiple investments in a similar space to improve the outcomes of success
quizSrc.definition: A. Consolidating interests through mergers and acquisitions  B. Locking out smaller players, leading to monopolies or cartels

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are tasks in the overall risk management process? (Select three.)A. MitigationB. DeploymentC. IdentificationD. EliminationE. Analysis
quizSrc.definition: A. Mitigation  C. Identification  E. Analysis

quizSrc.term: Which of the following risk analysis methods use words like "likely," "unlikely," and "rare" to describe the likelihood of risk, and words like "low," "medium," and "high" to describe the impact of risk? (Select two.) | Semi-qualitative analysis | Qualitative analysis | Quantitative analysis | Semi-quantitative analysis
quizSrc.definition: Semi-qualitative analysis | Qualitative analysis

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is not a valid risk response technique?A. TransferB. AcceptC. IgnoreD. Avoid
quizSrc.definition: C. Ignore

quizSrc.term: Which of the following statements are correct about a variable that is normally distributed? (Select two.)A. Less than half of all measurements fall within one standard deviation of the mean.B. The mean, median, and mode of all measurements is the same, and all are located at the center of the distribution.C. The variable's distribution, when graphed, exhibits a symmetrical bell shape.D. The tails of a normal distribution are denser than the center.
quizSrc.definition: B. The mean, median, and mode of all measurements is the same, and all are located at the center of the distribution.  C. The variable's distribution, when graphed, exhibits a symmetrical bell shape.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following statements accurately describes variance?A. Variance measures how much a variable's distribution differs from a normal distribution. B. Variance measures the shape of the tails in a distribution relative to the center. C. Variance measures how far a data example is from the mean.D. Variance measures the error between predicted values and actual values.
quizSrc.definition: C. Variance measures how far a data example is from the mean.

quizSrc.term: In the following scatter plot, the GrossIncome variable is plotted against the Revenue variable. What type of correlation does this plot suggest?A. There is a weak positive correlation between both variables. XB. There is a strong positive correlation between both variables. C. There is a strong negative correlation between both variables.D. There is a weak negative correlation between both variables.
quizSrc.definition: B. There is a strong positive correlation between both variables.

quizSrc.term: How do AI and other data-driven technologies use probability?A. By determining the objective likelihood of some event happeningB. By providing a model of belief about the likelihood of some event happeningC. By guaranteeing that some event will occur with 100% likelihoodD. By estimating the likelihood of some event happening without input data
quizSrc.definition: B. By providing a model of belief about the likelihood of some event happening

quizSrc.term: You have a dataset of customers that includes each customer's gender, location, and other personal attributes. The label you are trying to predict is how much sales revenue each customer is likely to generate for the business based on these attributes. What type of machine learning outcome is this problem suited for? | Dimensionality reduction | Clustering | Regression | Classification
quizSrc.definition: Regression

quizSrc.term: You're training a model to classify whether or not a bridge is likely to collapse given several factors. You have a dataset of thousands of existing bridges and their attributes, where each bridge is labeled as having collapsed or not collapsed. Only a handful of bridges in the dataset are labeled as having collapsed—the rest are labeled as not collapsed. Given your goal of minimizing bridge collapse and the severe harm it can cause, which of the following metrics would be most useful for evaluating the model? | Accuracy | Recall | Precision | Confusion matrix
quizSrc.definition: Recall

quizSrc.term: Which of the following metrics is used to evaluate a linear regression machine learning model?A. Receiver operating characteristic (ROC) B. Cost functionC. Goodhart's Law D. Accuracy
quizSrc.definition: B. Cost function

quizSrc.term: Which of the following best describes a marketing persona?A. A description of a type of character based upon demographics, habits, and interestsB. A character that encapsulates a brand's personalityC. An individual who assists with the activity of marketingD. The emotional impression that a customer has about a product or category of goods
quizSrc.definition: A. A description of a type of character based upon demographics, habits, and interests

quizSrc.term: Which of the following best describes the use case for zero-knowledge protocols (ZKPs)?A. Handling divide-by-zero errors in computing softwareB. Proving that something exists, but not the specificsC. Choosing what to do when you have zero knowledge of a subjectD. Being made aware of when the battery in a product is past its zero point
quizSrc.definition: B. Proving that something exists, but not the specifics

quizSrc.term: Which of the following elements constitute PII? (Select two.)A. Telephone numbersB. Device IDsC. Cookies and tokensD. Passport numbers
quizSrc.definition: A. Telephone numbers  D. Passport numbers

quizSrc.term: Which of the following elements should be communicated with end users when negotiating ethical access to a user's data? (Select two.) | An offer of money or other incentives to relinquish user's rights | The monetary value of that data | The intention behind a certain activity or request | A request for consent to perform an action
quizSrc.definition: The intention behind a certain activity or request | A request for consent to perform an action

quizSrc.term: Which of the following describes the technique of homomorphic encryption?A. A method of mitigating biased algorithms through enhanced secrecy.B. A method of swapping public and private keys between hosts.C. A method of cryptography that hides data inside other data.D. A method of performing operations on encrypted data.
quizSrc.definition: D. A method of performing operations on encrypted data.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following describe aspects of secondary data usage that might increase ethical risks? (Select two.)A. Data applied to secondary purposes may expose private aspects or diminish personal dignityB. Additional organizations and processors may now have access to the dataC. Encryption of data makes it harder to processD. Secondary data may be more expensive
quizSrc.definition: A. Data applied to secondary purposes may expose private aspects or diminish personal dignity  B. Additional organizations and processors may now have access to the data

quizSrc.term: Which of the following provide a user with more meaningful choices regarding how their data is being used? (Select two.)A. Whether the data is used by a person of a certain genderB. The format that the data is stored inC. Granular or modular control over data usageD. Opt-out/opt-in mechanisms
quizSrc.definition: C. Granular or modular control over data usage  D. Opt-out/opt-in mechanisms

quizSrc.term: Which of the following refer to legal regulations or industry frameworks for protecting data? (Select two.)A. CE markB. NIST Privacy FrameworkC. ISO 9000D. HIPAA
quizSrc.definition: B. NIST Privacy Framework  D. HIPAA

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are prerequisites for high-level digital security and trust mechanisms? (Select two.)A. AuthorizationB. KindnessC. AuthenticationD. Reputation
quizSrc.definition: A. Authorization  C. Authentication

quizSrc.term: Which of the following describe a process of cross-correlation of data? (Select two.)A. Discovering new information via inferenceB. Comparing people of different demographic groupsC. Analysing an individual's emotional stimulus and response patternsD. Comparing multiple data points or sets
quizSrc.definition: A. Discovering new information via inference  D. Comparing multiple data points or sets

quizSrc.term: What does the acronym RACI stand for?A. Relatable, Agreeable, Commendable, IrascibleB. Redesignable, Accessible, Collected, InformativeC. Responsible, Accessible, Consulted, ImprovisedD. Responsible, Accountable, Consulted, Informed
quizSrc.definition: D. Responsible, Accountable, Consulted, Informed

quizSrc.term: Which of the following describes extrajudicial judgment?A. A ruling or scoring made outside of a court.B. Unusual interpretation of law outside of its typical meaning.C. Applying law from one jurisdiction within another.D. Transferring defendants from one jurisdiction to another for trial.
quizSrc.definition: A. A ruling or scoring made outside of a court.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following elements might be considered moderately affected in an Impact Level 2 Algorithmic Impact Assessment? (Select two.)A. A brief delay in the conveyance of a commercial transaction.B. The health and well-being of individuals or communities.C. A loss of life resulting from specific circumstances.D. The rights of individuals or communities.
quizSrc.definition: B. The health and well-being of individuals or communities.  D. The rights of individuals or communities.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following describes automation bias?A. Bias that is subconscious, committed during a state of automata.B. Bias against automation by people worried about their jobs.C. Bias of people towards overly trusting in automation.D. Bias enabled or perpetuated by machine learning.
quizSrc.definition: C. Bias of people towards overly trusting in automation.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are likely benefits of having defined organizational policies? (Select two.)A. It supports consistency of behavior and unification of culture.B. It supports accountability and makes it more explicit.C. It supports improved sales and marketing results.D. It supports profitable research innovations and intellectual property.
quizSrc.definition: A. It supports consistency of behavior and unification of culture.  B. It supports accountability and makes it more explicit.

quizSrc.term: How might a non-stochastic decision tree be considered a black box algorithm?A. If the algorithm is contained within an embedded system.B. If the model is far too complex to be readily understood by human beings.C. If the algorithm serves as part of a data recorder.D. If the model is expressed in an annotated visual form.
quizSrc.definition: B. If the model is far too complex to be readily understood by human beings.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are potential ethical benefits of conducting pilot testing prior to the release of emerging technologies? (Select two.)A. It certifies that a product's developers are legally accountable.B. It reveals any gaps in accountability or auditability.C. It minimizes the impact of any ethical issues which may emerge.D. It demonstrates that the system is functional as early as possible in order to satisfy senior management and investor stakeholders.
quizSrc.definition: B. It reveals any gaps in accountability or auditability.  C. It minimizes the impact of any ethical issues which may emerge.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are important steps to document during an auditing process? (Select two.)A. Provide significant advance notice before an audit.B. Specify a purpose for the audit or an agenda to be covered.C. Specify and document what precisely is being audited.D. Document the audit procedures to be followed.
quizSrc.definition: C. Specify and document what precisely is being audited.  D. Document the audit procedures to be followed.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are common key performance indicators (KPIs) within dashboards of data-driven systems? (Select two.)A. Model training timeB. Operating cashflow forecastC. Performance metrics, such as accuracy and cost functionsD. Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA)
quizSrc.definition: A. Model training time  C. Performance metrics, such as accuracy and cost functions

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are likely examples of a leverageable third party data-driven or data-related product? (Select two.)A. Data annotation and augmentation toolsB. Compiled modelsC. Management oversightD. Product design lifecycle
quizSrc.definition: A. Data annotation and augmentation tools  B. Compiled models

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is an explainability risk of self-learning models?A. Self-learning models are unable to generate decisions as output.B. Self-learning models may introduce new data you're unaware of.C. Self-learning models are black boxes whose decisions cannot be understood.D. Self-learning models can corrupt data or otherwise make it unreadable.
quizSrc.definition: B. Self-learning models may introduce new data you're unaware of.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is a transparency risk of closed source software?A. Closed source software includes obfuscated code that cannot be read by a human.B. Closed source software cannot be shared with business partners.C. Closed source software cannot be reviewed by the organization that developed it.D. Closed source software may not be accessible to independent auditors.
quizSrc.definition: D. Closed source software may not be accessible to independent auditors.

quizSrc.term: A disruptive user on a social media site is subjected to a shadow ban. Which of the following might be an indication of that shadow ban?A. A user logs in one day to find a message from a site administrator saying that the user has been banned.B. A user logs in one day to find that they have been asked to discontinue their disruptive behavior, or they will be banned.C. A user logs in one day to find that their posting privileges have been revoked.D. A user logs in one day to find that they are able to post, but receive no direct responses.
quizSrc.definition: D. A user logs in one day to find that they are able to post, but receive no direct responses.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is an effort to turn black box AI models into models whose decisions are easier to understand?A. Explainable AIB. Human-in-the-loopC. Self-learning modelsD. Neural networks
quizSrc.definition: A. Explainable AI

quizSrc.term: You want to solicit feedback from users who are seeking explanations about your AI products and services. So, you decide to place a form on your marketing website that users can fill out. Which of the following is the best way to structure that form for the purpose of collecting useful feedback?A. Provide a series of yes or no questions with radio buttons where users select their respective answers.B. Provide a large, unrestricted text box where users can enter their thoughts at length.C. Provide a series of open questions with a single-line entry field where users can provide short answers.D. Provide a drop-down menu of feedback categories that users can select from, with a promise that you'll follow up via email.
quizSrc.definition: B. Provide a large, unrestricted text box where users can enter their thoughts at length.

quizSrc.term: You're the recipient of some data collected by a third party that you'll use in training an AI model. As per your business agreement, the third-party discloser of the data requests that you explain how you plan to use the data. At what point in the process should you provide this explanation? | At the point of planning the AI system. | At the point of evaluating the model. | At the point of collecting the data. | At the point of training the model.
quizSrc.definition: At the point of planning the AI system.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are potential training data inadequacies that you should communicate to your users in support of transparency? (Select two.)A. The amount of time it took to collect the data.B. Any missing values in the dataset and how they were handled.C. The relatively large size of a dataset used in training.D. Any known bias in the sample data.
quizSrc.definition: B. Any missing values in the dataset and how they were handled.  D. Any known bias in the sample data.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is a technique used by the Python tool Alibi to produce a subset of features that will usually result in the same model prediction?A. Anchor ExplanationsB. Shapley valueC. Local Interpretable Model-Agnostic ExplanationsD. Perturbation
quizSrc.definition: A. Anchor Explanations

quizSrc.term: Which of the following Python tools is designed to integrate with Google's Cloud AI platform? | ELI5 | What-If | SHAP | LIME
quizSrc.definition: What-If

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are typically true when comparing the LIME tool with the SHAP tool? (Select two.)A. LIME outputs results faster than SHAP.B. LIME is less accurate than SHAP.C. LIME supports fewer types of models than SHAP.D. LIME supports more programming languages than SHAP.
quizSrc.definition: A. LIME outputs results faster than SHAP.  B. LIME is less accurate than SHAP.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following types of bias emerges when the same data is sampled over and over again, limiting a model's perspective? | Confirmation bias | Reinforcement bias | Temporal bias | Implicit bias
quizSrc.definition: Reinforcement bias

quizSrc.term: Why is a model that has been overfitted to its training data a source of fairness risk?A. Because the model is too complex.B. Because the model includes too much noise.C. Because the model won't generalize to the entire population.D. Because the model has a temporal bias.
quizSrc.definition: C. Because the model won't generalize to the entire population.

quizSrc.term: Which type of edge case is caused by data outside the normal distribution?A. ErrorsB. NoiseC. OverfittingD. Outliers
quizSrc.definition: D. Outliers

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is a function of exploratory data analysis (EDA)?A. To evaluate the decisions made by the model after training on the data.B. To evaluate the quality of data before it is used to train a model.C. To evaluate the methods used to collect the data.D. To evaluate the organization's project management structure for the AI project.
quizSrc.definition: B. To evaluate the quality of data before it is used to train a model.

quizSrc.term: How can persona modeling be used to identify potential biases in a machine learning model?A. The persona may show that specific users are a source of bias.B. The persona may reveal overfitting issues in a model that result from bias.C. The persona may identify noise and other edge cases that lead to bias.D. The persona may represent groups of people that could be susceptible to bias.
quizSrc.definition: D. The persona may represent groups of people that could be susceptible to bias.

quizSrc.term: In a classification model that determines whether or not a customer qualifies for a coupon, a significantly lower percentage of males qualified than females. Which of the following types of discrimination does this outcome potentially represent?A. Disparate impactB. Disparate treatmentC. Disparate non-impactD. Disparate mistreatment
quizSrc.definition: A. Disparate impact

quizSrc.term: Which of the following describes the purpose of a STEEPV analysis?A. To perform a strategic analysis of user needs and behaviors.B. To perform a strategic analysis of how bias can manifest in AI products.C. To perform a strategic analysis of how internal office politics impact business operations.D. To perform a strategic analysis of how external environments impact business operations.
quizSrc.definition: D. To perform a strategic analysis of how external environments impact business operations.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are best practices for incorporating inclusive design in AI projects? (Select two.)A. Leverage customer input to reduce bias.B. Consider bias a spectrum.C. Keep machines and humans separate.D. Solve for many, extend to one.
quizSrc.definition: A. Leverage customer input to reduce bias.  B. Consider bias a spectrum.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following describes the AI Fairness 360 project?A. An AI product that represents a completely fair model for AI practitioners to use as a benchmark.B. A checklist for machine learning practitioners to follow when training fair AI models.C. A global initiative that promotes fairness in AI through seminars, conferences, and other community-driven activities.D. An open source library that evaluates models for bias and provides mitigation tactics to reduce that bias.
quizSrc.definition: D. An open source library that evaluates models for bias and provides mitigation tactics to reduce that bias.

quizSrc.term: What is the primary advantage of radioactive data tracing over past techniques that modify input in order to determine whether or not that input was used in training?A. Radioactive data tracing doesn't impact a model's performance.B. Radioactive data tracing can be used to modify the label.C. Radioactive data tracing targets language-based input.D. Radioactive data tracing makes the modification perceptible to human beings.
quizSrc.definition: A. Radioactive data tracing doesn't impact a model's performance.

quizSrc.term: What does the acronym SIEM stand for in a cybersecurity context?A. Social, interpersonal, empathic, mentalB. Serial input to externalized modulationC. Selective information extrapolation methodsD. Security information and event management
quizSrc.definition: D. Security information and event management

quizSrc.term: Which of the following sources does a SIEM system typically pull data from? (Select two.)A. Personnel emailsB. Encrypted personal dataC. System event logsD. Network intrusion detection alerts
quizSrc.definition: C. System event logs  D. Network intrusion detection alerts

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are likely to be found within a penetration test rules of engagement (ROE)? (Select two.)A. What systems may be targetedB. How long CCTV camera recordings should be maintainedC. The appropriate length and complexity of employee passwordsD. What methods of attack are legitimate
quizSrc.definition: A. What systems may be targeted  D. What methods of attack are legitimate

quizSrc.term: Which team typically oversees penetration test operations and adherence to the rules of engagement (ROE)?A. Blue teamB. White teamC. Purple teamD. Red team
quizSrc.definition: B. White team

quizSrc.term: Which of the following benefits can be gained from establishing baseline system behaviors? (Select two.)A. Optimizing costs of operationB. Holding employees more accountableC. Tracking deviance from normsD. Restoring compromised functionality through a system rollback
quizSrc.definition: C. Tracking deviance from norms  D. Restoring compromised functionality through a system rollback

quizSrc.term: Which of the following could Nmap, Wireshark, or Metasploit be applied to for ethical purposes?A. Business continuity planningB. Persona modelingC. Attack simulationsD. Criminal exploitation
quizSrc.definition: C. Attack simulations

quizSrc.term: What does the initialism CIA stand for in a data security context?A. Conformity, influence, adaptationB. Communicability, interpretation, accessibilityC. Compliance, integrity, accountabilityD. Confidentiality, integrity, availability
quizSrc.definition: D. Confidentiality, integrity, availability

quizSrc.term: SSL, TLS, and SSH are all forms of...A. Media codecsB. Version control systemsC. Encryption protocolsD. Computer forensics tools
quizSrc.definition: C. Encryption protocols

quizSrc.term: What does the acronym CSIRT stand for in a security context?A. Conformance strategy, immutability, reliability, trustworthinessB. Computer security immediate readiness toolsC. Computer science, Internet, real-time interaction, technologyD. Cybersecurity incident response team
quizSrc.definition: D. Cybersecurity incident response team

quizSrc.term: In which of the following could STRIDE or VAST classifications be applied?A. Network optimization toolsB. Black box mitigation methodsC. Bias mitigation techniquesD. Threat modeling or analysis tools
quizSrc.definition: D. Threat modeling or analysis tools

quizSrc.term: Why is it important to categorize ethical risks into different types? (Select two.)A. It makes it easier for us to identify and manage different types of risks.B. It helps us understand the many complexities involved in different types of ethical risks.C. It helps us consider risk mitigation in terms of universal tactics that apply to all potential kinds of ethical risk.D. It ensures that customers and other external stakeholders know that we take ethical risks seriously.
quizSrc.definition: A. It makes it easier for us to identify and manage different types of risks.  B. It helps us understand the many complexities involved in different types of ethical risks.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following communication tactics help uphold transparency and explainability from the customer perspective? (Select two.)A. Providing guidelines for how customers can keep their private data secure when using data-driven systems.B. Providing information about data-driven systems in simple, easy-to-understand terms.C. Providing in-depth white papers on the algorithms that underlie data-driven systems.D. Providing prompt responses to customer questions about the decisions made by data-driven systems.
quizSrc.definition: B. Providing information about data-driven systems in simple, easy-to-understand terms.  D. Providing prompt responses to customer questions about the decisions made by data-driven systems.

quizSrc.term: Why is it important to engage stakeholders at the beginning of the ethical risk management process?A. It proves that you are completely equipped to address any ethical risks in your data-driven systems.B. It demonstrates that the organization is committed to accountability and transparency in their data-driven systems.C. It helps the organization avoid legal trouble during the development and deployment of data-driven systems.D. It lets stakeholders know that the organization cannot address ethical risks in data-driven systems without input from stakeholders first.
quizSrc.definition: B. It demonstrates that the organization is committed to accountability and transparency in their data-driven systems.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following situations would most likely require communication to external stakeholders? (Select two.) | The organization plans to adopt a new ethical framework to support the implementation of an AI system. | The organization's change management strategy has been modified. | The organization's data-driven service will receive an update that enhances its accuracy. | The organization's AI product has a defect and needs to be recalled.
quizSrc.definition: The organization plans to adopt a new ethical framework to support the implementation of an AI system. | The organization's AI product has a defect and needs to be recalled.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are useful strategies for communicating ethical risks to the organization? (Select two.)A. Provide information only when solicitedB. Disseminate information in multiple formatsC. Communicate information through a single voiceD. Communicate information in real time
quizSrc.definition: B. Disseminate information in multiple formats  D. Communicate information in real time

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are useful strategies for communicating ethical risks to society? (Select two.)A. Ensure communication policies are diverse, inclusive, and equitableB. Provide access to information on a need-to-know basisC. Limit the flow of information to one direction: organization to publicD. Be culturally sensitive and culturally aware during communication
quizSrc.definition: A. Ensure communication policies are diverse, inclusive, and equitable  D. Be culturally sensitive and culturally aware during communication

quizSrc.term: When conducting a business impact assessment (BIA), why is it important to interview or survey personnel at the ground level, not just managers and other higher-ups?A. They may have more institutional knowledge about a subject than managers.B. They have a greater obligation to answer questions.C. They are more likely to find the time to complete an interview or survey.D. They are more likely to be candid and give forthright responses.
quizSrc.definition: A. They may have more institutional knowledge about a subject than managers.

quizSrc.term: As a result of failing to communicate ethical risks, the organization's reputation suffers and customers are less confident in the organization. What direct impact can this have? | Customers will find it more difficult to use your products and services. | Morale amongst internal personnel will drop, as will productivity. | The organization will be more likely to draw the attention of legal and regulatory auditors. | The products or services the organization creates will have less of an impact in the marketplace.
quizSrc.definition: A. The products or services the organization creates will have less of an impact in the marketplace.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following should be conducted as part of a risk communication strategy in order to ensure the organization is upholding its regulatory obligations?A. Business impact assessment (BIA)B. Ethical risk reviewC. Public relations campaignD. Compliance audit
quizSrc.definition: D. Compliance audit

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are useful strategies for communicating ethical risks to the individual? (Select two.)A. Ensure individuals feel that they have input into the processB. Ensure individuals understand the specific details of each risk they are affected byC. Communicate to individuals proactively rather than reactivelyD. Inform individuals of how they are obligated to mitigate risks to themselves
quizSrc.definition: A. Ensure individuals feel that they have input into the process  C. Communicate to individuals proactively rather than reactively

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is a best practice for incorporating diversity, equity, and inclusiveness in communication?A. Ensure multiple groups of people based on race, gender, etc., are communicating in different waysB. Focus on the organization's intended message rather than incorporating feedback from external stakeholdersC. Reassure customers that the organization is diverse, equitable, and inclusiveD. Promote an organizational culture that embraces these values
quizSrc.definition: D. Promote an organizational culture that embraces these values

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is an important concept to consider as part of building an organizational philosophy?A. Adopting philosophies already created by other organizationsB. Anticipating future implications of that philosophyC. Considering internal stakeholder needs above all elseD. Putting ethical principles into practice
quizSrc.definition: B. Anticipating future implications of that philosophy

quizSrc.term: The endorsement of which of the following types of stakeholder is most critical when developing mission and vision statements?A. CustomersB. C-suite executivesC. EmployeesD. Department heads
quizSrc.definition: C. Employees

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is a benefit of providing disclosure statements?A. It enables the organization to mitigate ethical risks.B. It creates an ethical framework from which the organization can operate.C. It demonstrates that the organization lacks ethical conflicts.D. It demonstrates that the organization has a commitment to openness.
quizSrc.definition: D. It demonstrates that the organization has a commitment to openness.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is the most important factor to consider when developing corporate reports?A. Who the intended audience of the report isB. Whether or not it's necessary to include financial information in the reportC. Who is the most qualified person to deliver the reportD. Where the data used in the report comes from and how accurate it is
quizSrc.definition: D. Where the data used in the report comes from and how accurate it is

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are important factors to consider when developing a media campaign? (Select two.)A. The effect the campaign has on the organization's bottom lineB. The environment in which the campaign will be launchedC. The risks that will be talked about in the campaignD. The time-sensitive nature of communication in the campaign
quizSrc.definition: B. The environment in which the campaign will be launched  D. The time-sensitive nature of communication in the campaign

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are distinguishing characteristics of a "living" public education campaign? (Select two.)A. The campaign is continuously improved upon.B. The campaign fosters a relationship between the organization and its stakeholders.C. The campaign must be self-sustaining.D. The campaign cannot be modified without the consent of the organization.
quizSrc.definition: A. The campaign is continuously improved upon.  B. The campaign fosters a relationship between the organization and its stakeholders.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is a best practice when participating in media inquiries? (Select two.) ????????????A. Divulge only the information that you are required to by lawB. Get your message out as quickly as possibleC. Only agree to speak to media outlets that are favorable to your organizationD. Ensure your message is consistent
quizSrc.definition: D. Ensure your message is consistent

quizSrc.term: What is the benefit of hosting a virtual reality press conference over a traditional in-person press conference?A. The conference can be interactive without the participants needing to be co-located.B. The participants will be impressed by your leveraging of new and exciting technologies.C. It will be easier to communicate your overall message to your audience.D. The conference will be easily accessible to all willing participants.
quizSrc.definition: A. The conference can be interactive without the participants needing to be co-located.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are important qualities of a press release? (Select two.) | It's non-interactive | It's in a digital format | It's concise | It's delivered on a single platform
quizSrc.definition: It's in a digital format | It's concise

quizSrc.term: How does the low likelihood of a crisis relate to its potential impact?A. A crisis with low likelihood tends to have high impact.B. A crisis with low likelihood tends to have little to no effect on its impact.C. A crisis with low likelihood tends to have low impact.D. A crisis with low likelihood tends to have moderate impact.
quizSrc.definition: A. A crisis with low likelihood tends to have high impact.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is the most important idea that a crisis communication program should manage? | Internal stakeholder consensus about how to approach a crisis | The individual details of a crisis | The real-world effects of a crisis | The public's perception of a crisis
quizSrc.definition: The public's perception of a crisis

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are important to provide to a crisis communication team? (Select two.)A. Permission to tell the public what they want to hearB. Access to adequate resourcesC. Clear direction on the roles and responsibilities of team membersD. The ability to work independently of the crisis management team
quizSrc.definition: B. Access to adequate resources  C. Clear direction on the roles and responsibilities of team members

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are desired qualities when choosing a spokesperson for your organization? (Select two.)A. Defensive when challenged with difficult situationsB. Patient when addressing tough questions or concernsC. Lighthearted when dealing with serious topicsD. Articulate when communicating important details
quizSrc.definition: B. Patient when addressing tough questions or concerns  D. Articulate when communicating important details

quizSrc.term: The organization needs to ask itself about any quality control issues it may be having. Which of the following processes is most suitable for asking and answering that question?A. Business impact assessmentB. Business continuity planC. Vulnerability auditD. Lessons learned report
quizSrc.definition: C. Vulnerability audit

quizSrc.term: Which of the following practices can help an organization prepare to uphold business continuity in the event of a crisis? (Select two.)A. Informing external stakeholders of suspected incidentsB. Evaluating the effects that the crisis has on the businessC. Performing a business impact assessment (BIA)D. Rehearsing business continuity tasks
quizSrc.definition: C. Performing a business impact assessment (BIA)  D. Rehearsing business continuity tasks

quizSrc.term: How can you leverage emerging technologies like AI in disaster recovery plans (DRP)?A. By using deep learning techniques to bolster the organization's defense against disasters.B. By using natural language processing (NLP) techniques to ensure the DRP document is understandable and free of typographic errors.C. By using data-driven techniques to inform the strategies behind the DRP.D. By using AI decision-making systems to decide whether or not a DRP is necessary for your organization.
quizSrc.definition: C. By using data-driven techniques to inform the strategies behind the DRP.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is the first step in developing an incident response plan (IRP)?A. Identifying risksB. Consulting internal stakeholdersC. Forming a teamD. Taking feedback from customers
quizSrc.definition: A. Identifying risks

quizSrc.term: Which of the following activities are important to conduct in a post-crisis phase? (Select two.)A. Restructuring the response team for future crisesB. Communicating information about the crisis with stakeholdersC. Discussing lessons learned during the crisisD. Performing a vulnerability audit of all affected systems
quizSrc.definition: B. Communicating information about the crisis with stakeholders  C. Discussing lessons learned during the crisis

quizSrc.term: Why is it important not to review a crisis too soon after it has concluded? (Select two.)A. By reviewing a crisis too soon, you may not have collected all of the useful details.B. By reviewing a crisis too soon, you run the risk of violating compliance requirements.C. By reviewing a crisis too soon, you can exasperate the people involved.D. By reviewing a crisis too soon, you can unknowingly extend the effects of that crisis.
quizSrc.definition: A. By reviewing a crisis too soon, you may not have collected all of the useful details.  C. By reviewing a crisis too soon, you can exasperate the people involved.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are tools of an effective media communication plan? (Select two.)A. Mission statementB. Video briefingC. Press releaseD. Public education campaign
quizSrc.definition: B. Video briefing  C. Press release
