quizSrc.term: What is the purpose of a holding statement in crisis and media communications?A. To pre-write communications before they are neededB. To prevent personnel from communicating prematurelyC. To order the business to temporarily halt certain operationsD. To retain the services of specific media outlets
quizSrc.definition: A. To pre-write communications before they are needed

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are effective strategies when making statements on social media? (Select two.)A. Communicating only as neededB. Presenting a face of the organizationC. Focusing on positive feedbackD. Being honest and up front
quizSrc.definition: B. Presenting a face of the organization  D. Being honest and up front

quizSrc.term: What is the primary purpose of obtaining feedback about an ethical crisis?A. To make operational improvementsB. To motivate internal personnelC. To appeases concerned stakeholdersD. To demonstrate compliance
quizSrc.definition: A. To make operational improvements

quizSrc.term: Which of the following negative consequences is the direct result of failing to be truthful in communicating about a crisis?A. Reputational damageB. DiscriminationC. Financial lossD. Security risk
quizSrc.definition: A. Reputational damage

quizSrc.term: When you deliver periodic statements about a crisis to the media, what should the first statement do?A. Provide in-depth details about the situationB. Accept responsibility for perceived problemsC. Survey public opinion of the organizationD. Set the tone of what is to follow
quizSrc.definition: D. Set the tone of what is to follow

quizSrc.term: Why is it important to build a "reservoir" of goodwill with the media? | The media will be less likely to publish a story about a crisis right away, opting to wait for your approval instead. | The media will be less likely to accuse the organization of being malicious or negligent in the event of a crisis. | The media will be more likely to give the organization the benefit of the doubt in the event of a crisis. | The media will be more likely to advocate for your organization in the event of a crisis.
quizSrc.definition: The media will be more likely to give the organization the benefit of the doubt in the event of a crisis.

quizSrc.term: Why is it important to leverage legacy media like print, television, and radio, rather than just digital media?A. Legacy media channels are more effective at broadcasting a messageB. Digital media platforms are seen as less respectable or trustworthyC. Not everyone has access to digital media platformsD. It is easier to disseminate a message through legacy media channels
quizSrc.definition: C. Not everyone has access to digital media platforms

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is a useful strategy when communicating the truth about a crisis becomes difficult?A. Tell some truths, but withhold othersB. Provide information gradually, over multiple communicationsC. Promise to provide information at a later dateD. Put all of the information out there at once
quizSrc.definition: D. Put all of the information out there at once

quizSrc.term: How can sentiment analysis be useful in social media communication? | It can determine which users have the largest influence on your reputation, and therefore which users you should communicate with. | It can shape the content and delivery of the message based on users' perceptions of the organization or technology. | It can classify customers as loyal or disloyal, helping you target customers differently in your communications. | It can determine how to construct a message that influences users to be more positive about the organization or technology.
quizSrc.definition: It can shape the content and delivery of the message based on users' perceptions of the organization or technology.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following describes ethics washing?A. No attempt is made towards genuine ethical action.B. Superficial promises are replaced by genuine ethical action.C. Genuine ethical action is used to wash over previous mistakes.D. Genuine ethical action gets replaced by superficial promises.
quizSrc.definition: D. Genuine ethical action gets replaced by superficial promises.

quizSrc.term: Is an open door policy equivalent to ensuring employee voice?A. Yes, because both allow employees to speak up.B. Yes, because an open door policy is essential for employee voice.C. No, because an open door policy is the opposite of employee voice.D. No, because an open door policy does not ensure employees feel heard.
quizSrc.definition: D. No, because an open door policy does not ensure employees feel heard.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following might be a risk of not having an ethical organizational culture?A. Employees might face cognitive dissonance.B. Employees are more likely to express their opinions about the company.C. Employees will experience a faster approval process to get a product launched.D. Employees might be less interested in their careers.
quizSrc.definition: A. Employees might face cognitive dissonance.

quizSrc.term: Which expression best characterizes what a company or organizational culture is? | "This is how we want this done." | "This is what we're told to do." | "This is how things are done around here." | "It is what it is."
quizSrc.definition: "This is how things are done around here."

quizSrc.term: Which of the following describes change management?A. A collective term for all approaches to prepare, support, and help individuals, teams, and organizations in fostering an ethical organizational culture.B. A collective term used to describe how employees are able to voice their concerns to facilitate change in their organization.C. A collective term used to explain how organizations facilitate change in a product after receiving negative feedback.D. A collective term for all approaches to prepare, support, and help individuals, teams, and organizations in making organizational change.
quizSrc.definition: D. A collective term for all approaches to prepare, support, and help individuals, teams, and organizations in making organizational change.

quizSrc.term: Which organizational resource is most commonly used in terms of fostering an ethical organizational culture?A. Informational resourcesB. Human resourcesC. Physical resourcesD. Financial resources
quizSrc.definition: B. Human resources

quizSrc.term: Which of the following describes the purpose of having an Ethics Board for a data-driven organization? | An Ethics Board can increase transparency into how the organization uses AI or autonomous technologies. | An Ethics Board can help maintain an organization's values-based intentions and decrease the inherent dangers of autonomous technologies. | An Ethics Board can help maintain an organization's values-based intentions and increase transparency into how they use data-driven technologies. | An Ethics Board can help maintain an organization's profit margins and increase transparency into how they increase their profits.
quizSrc.definition: An Ethics Board can help maintain an organization's values-based intentions and increase transparency into how they use data-driven technologies.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is a potential benefit of having an ethical organizational culture?A. More employees are likely to switch careers.B. Employees are more likely to listen to their superiors.C. The company will get an increase in stock value.D. Employees will feel a sense of responsibility and loyalty.
quizSrc.definition: D. Employees will feel a sense of responsibility and loyalty.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following describes employee voice?A. The amount of feedback that employees are willing to share with their fellow coworkers to boost company morale and efficiency.B. The amount of voluntary effort that employees are willing to spend to file complaints about conditions of the company or organization.C. The amount of voluntary effort employees are willing to put into communicating suggestions, opinions, concerns, and ideas that can be used to make improvements.D. The likelihood of employees voicing their concerns about the company because they want to improve company performance.
quizSrc.definition: C. The amount of voluntary effort employees are willing to put into communicating suggestions, opinions, concerns, and ideas that can be used to make improvements.

quizSrc.term: What is the purpose of ethics training in regard to fostering an ethical organizational culture?A. To help employees develop their ability to follow instructions and identify potential avenues to improve efficiency and output.B. To help employees develop their ability to communicate in the workplace and identify actions and behaviors that can help boost company morale.C. To help employees develop their ability to recognize and promote ethical decisions in the workplace and identify ethical and unethical actions and behaviors.D. To help employees develop their ability to identify potential misconduct in the workplace and report those incidents to the proper departments.
quizSrc.definition: C. To help employees develop their ability to recognize and promote ethical decisions in the workplace and identify ethical and unethical actions and behaviors.

quizSrc.term: Why is corporate governance important when thinking about ethical considerations for the development of data-driven technologies?A. It helps the organization showcase to its customers that it has ethical guidelines.B. It binds the employees in a moral code that limits the kind of actions they can engage in.C. It provides an accountability framework for stakeholders of the organization to prevent ethical violations.D. It helps the organization have a document to point towards in case an ethical violation occurs.
quizSrc.definition: C. It provides an accountability framework for stakeholders of the organization to prevent ethical violations.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following would be the most beneficial stage to hold ethical risk reviews for a new project that your team is undertaking?A. ConceptionB. DevelopmentC. DesignD. Deployment
quizSrc.definition: A. Conception

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is NOT a common consideration when looking at the major ethical frameworks?A. PrivacyB. TransparencyC. SecurityD. Humanity
quizSrc.definition: D. Humanity

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is an ethical benefit of incorporating fair competition considerations in a data-driven technology ecosystem?A. Lowering product and service costs for the usersB. Accelerating investments in research and developmentC. Encouraging product or service differentiationD. Consolidating products and services under a single organization
quizSrc.definition: C. Encouraging product or service differentiation

quizSrc.term: Which of the following principle sets are important for the creation of open data that is widely utilized?A. ISO 27017B. FATEC. ISO 27001D. FAIR
quizSrc.definition: D. FAIR

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is a misuse of intellectual property (IP) when it comes to ethical accountability for an organization?A. Filing a patent for the IP that makes non-obvious information known to the public.B. Enhancing the security posture of a product or service.C. Using IP as a defensive mechanism to eschew transparency requirements.D. Collecting returns on investments made in research and development.
quizSrc.definition: C. Using IP as a defensive mechanism to eschew transparency requirements.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is an ethical risk if there is non-compliance with legal and regulatory requirements within a jurisdiction ? (Select two).A. User discriminationB. Reputational harmC. Lack of transparencyD. Loss of profits
quizSrc.definition: A. User discrimination  C. Lack of transparency

quizSrc.term: Which of the following best explains why there is an emphasis on including human rights in the major ethical frameworks?A. They help to provide an anthropocentric frame for the ethical considerations.B. They help to satisfy legal and regulatory requirements and make the product compliant in the local jurisdiction.C. They are universal and provide scaffolding for all other ethical considerations.D. They allow an organization to deliver its products and services in a larger number of markets.
quizSrc.definition: C. They are universal and provide scaffolding for all other ethical considerations.

quizSrc.term: Why are environmental concerns important to consider in the ethical development of data-driven technologies?A. Data-driven technologies directly impact the environment through the invasive mining of resources to create the technologies.B. Data-driven technologies can cause secondary, indirect, or cumulative effects on the environment that might impact people in the long term.C. Data-driven technologies directly impact the environment through pollution.D. Data-driven technologies directly impact living things via displacement.
quizSrc.definition: B. Data-driven technologies can cause secondary, indirect, or cumulative effects on the environment that might impact people in the long term.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following presents the most important argument for why we need to consider the impact of AI on labor in the design, development, and deployment of data-driven technology?A. There may be an impact on worker productivity if they are not included in all phases.B. There might be potential labor rights and human rights violations.C. There is still a need for human workers in human-in-the-loop mechanisms.D. The organization would like to avoid having to deal with union concerns.
quizSrc.definition: B. There might be potential labor rights and human rights violations.

quizSrc.term: To which of the following groups would a code of ethics not be applicable?A. Business managers of the data-driven technology systemB. Data subjects of the data-driven technology systemC. Designers of the data-driven technology systemD. Developers of the data-driven technology system
quizSrc.definition: B. Data subjects of the data-driven technology system

quizSrc.term: Which of the following constitute internal stakeholders in the context of a code of ethics?A. DesignersB. RegulatorsC. Data subjectsD. Policymakers
quizSrc.definition: A. Designers

quizSrc.term: Which of the following constitute external stakeholders in the context of a code of ethics?A. RegulatorsB. DevelopersC. DesignersD. Business managers
quizSrc.definition: A. Regulators

quizSrc.term: How can you identify potential areas of concern for ethical practices when developing a code of ethics? (Select three).A. Rely on the requirements of government regulations.B. Obtain feedback from stakeholder focus groups.C. Rely on your own personal experiences.D. Identify prior issues with your product or service.E. Research similar organization's ethical mistakes and concerns.
quizSrc.definition: B. Obtain feedback from stakeholder focus groups.  D. Identify prior issues with your product or service.  E. Research similar organization's ethical mistakes and concerns.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are possible causes of the limited adoption of a code of ethics within an organization? (Select two).A. Comprehensive coverage of areas of concerns by the code of ethicsB. Lack of clarity in the code of ethicsC. Lack of awareness of the code of ethics and where it is meant to be appliedD. Prescriptive language used in the code of ethics
quizSrc.definition: B. Lack of clarity in the code of ethics  C. Lack of awareness of the code of ethics and where it is meant to be applied

quizSrc.term: Which style or tone is recommended for a code of ethics? (Select two.)A. Legal languageB. Plain languageC. Prescriptive languageD. Subjective language
quizSrc.definition: B. Plain language  C. Prescriptive language

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is a problematic reason to pilot a code of ethics prior to widespread deployment?A. The pilot phase demonstrates the seriousness of the organization with respect to its ethical responsibilities.B. The pilot phase helps to stress test a code of ethics in a real-world situation.C. The pilot phase helps to develop awareness and buy-in from the relevant stakeholders in the organization.D. The pilot phase helps to identify gaps in the current code of ethics.
quizSrc.definition: A. The pilot phase demonstrates the seriousness of the organization with respect to its ethical responsibilities.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is a reason to periodically update a code of ethics document?A. It is a fiduciary and regulatory responsibility for the organization to do so.B. It reinforces the presence of the code of ethics in the minds of the employees.C. It allows you to capture the evolving nature of the ethical risks of the product or service that you are developing.D. It signals that you care about ethics to internal and external stakeholders.
quizSrc.definition: C. It allows you to capture the evolving nature of the ethical risks of the product or service that you are developing.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following will ensure that a code of ethics is widely adopted within the organization?A. Integrating the code of ethics deeply into the existing workflows within the organization.B. Writing the code in legal language to ensure that it is compliant with the laws of the land.C. Making a public announcement with the creators of the code of ethics.D. Including the code of ethics in the legal documents signed by the employees.
quizSrc.definition: A. Integrating the code of ethics deeply into the existing workflows within the organization.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are reasons to design, develop, and deploy a code of ethics within an organization? (Select two).A. It compels employees to operate in an ethical and integral manner.B. It prevents regulatory scrutiny of the organization's practices.C. It lets external stakeholders know that you are an ethical company.D. It creates consistency in the ethical practices across the organization, rather than patchy implementation of the practices.
quizSrc.definition: A. It compels employees to operate in an ethical and integral manner.  D. It creates consistency in the ethical practices across the organization, rather than patchy implementation of the practices.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following helps to ensure that internal and external ethics policies are adhered to in practice?A. Having unambiguous procedures tied to the clauses of the policy.B. Ensuring the policies have ample room for flexibility in implementation.C. Including detailed legalese in the policy that mirrors regulatory requirements.D. Developing procedures first and then creating policies that reflect those procedures.
quizSrc.definition: A. Having unambiguous procedures tied to the clauses of the policy.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is an important reason to have a policy owner for internal and external ethics policies ?A. They can help to prevent changes from taking place in the policies over time by justifying their choices.B. The policy owner will write the policy, relying solely on their personal institutional knowledge.C. It helps to have a single person that can be held accountable in case something goes wrong.D. They can help to bring the right internal and external stakeholders together to help draft these ethics policies.
quizSrc.definition: D. They can help to bring the right internal and external stakeholders together to help draft these ethics policies.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is a reason to engage in a comprehensive information gathering phase before drafting your internal and external ethics policies?A. It helps to collect reaffirming evidence for your own ethical beliefs.B. It saves you effort if you just copy the existing ethics policies from other organizations.C. It helps to unearth best practices from peers in the industry.D. It provides examples of possible ethical pitfalls that the organization should avoid.
quizSrc.definition: C. It helps to unearth best practices from peers in the industry.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is a reason to engage external stakeholders during the development of internal and external ethics policies ?A. It can be used as an opportunity to demonstrate your ethical standpoints with both internal and external stakeholders.B. It can unearth new insights for how the products and services might be used in the target demographic community.C. It acts as a shielding mechanism for accountability in case an ethical violation occurs in the future.D. It helps to reinforce the cultural and contextual values of the employees by getting external validation.
quizSrc.definition: B. It can unearth new insights for how the products and services might be used in the target demographic community.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is an important action needed for the finalization of internal and external ethics policies before approval?A. Discarding open issues to provide a clean slate for the next iteration of the policiesB. Ensuring the policies are the same as those from other peer organizationsC. Testing the policy in an already deployed project settingD. Documenting the assumptions and choices made in the drafting of the policies
quizSrc.definition: D. Documenting the assumptions and choices made in the drafting of the policies

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is an essential asset that helps to operationalize the internal and external ethics policies via procedures?A. A description of the procedures in the annual report of the organization.B. A detailed report that presents the various scenarios using technical jargon.C. Concrete examples that show how the policies work in practice.D. A designated ethics lead who is solely responsible for the implementation of said procedures.
quizSrc.definition: C. Concrete examples that show how the policies work in practice.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is a key element of communications with internal and external stakeholders regarding an organization's ethics policies?A. Simple to follow examplesB. Flexible verbiageC. Dense procedural descriptionsD. Daily communications
quizSrc.definition: A. Simple to follow examples

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is an important reason for continually refreshing an organization's internal and external ethics policies?A. It helps maintain alignment of the policies with the cultural and contextual values of the organization's employees.B. It helps maintain alignment with the emergent risks and changing ethical posture of the products and services of the organization.C. It helps internal stakeholders justify the release of new product features or service upgrades.D. It helps demonstrate to senior management that work is being done on the internal and external ethics policies.
quizSrc.definition: B. It helps maintain alignment with the emergent risks and changing ethical posture of the products and services of the organization.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is a benefit of using focus groups over surveys?A. They allow for deeper engagement with the target demographic community.B. They are a more scalable option for the collection of information.C. They are an easier way to collect information from a target audience.D. They can provide more data through structured information gathering.
quizSrc.definition: A. They allow for deeper engagement with the target demographic community.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is a valid reason for tracking the number and severity of an organization's ethical violations?A. It can dissuade end users from scrutinizing the internal and external ethics policies.B. It can help provide qualitative information that can be used to improve the policies.C. It can replace the need for refreshing the internal and external ethics policies.D. It can help provide transparency around the efforts to improve the policies.
quizSrc.definition: D. It can help provide transparency around the efforts to improve the policies.

quizSrc.term: Based upon studies from conducted by accredited certification bodies and the Lumina Foundation, which of the following is true regarding professionals who hold industry validated certifications?A. They have greater potential to earn higher salaries than peers without professional certifications.B. They are more likely to be employed by enterprise level organizations.C. They demonstrate higher productivity than peers without professional certifications.D. They are statistically shown to have greater intelligence than their peers without professional certifications.
quizSrc.definition: A. They have greater potential to earn higher salaries than peers without professional certifications.

quizSrc.term: When scheduling your exam on Pearson VUE, you will be asked to provide information about yourself. Which of the following do you need to be sure to do when entering this information?A. Set up a unique email to receive exam information from Pearson VUE.B. Run the speed the test prior to entering your information.C. Match the government-issued ID that you will use to verify your identity on the day of the exam.D. Have your video camera on and set to the correct aspect ratio.
quizSrc.definition: C. Match the government-issued ID that you will use to verify your identity on the day of the exam.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is a noted difference between a certificate and a certification?A. Certifications are issued by industry certification bodies.B. Certifications cannot be revoked.C. Certifications are granted upon completion of a course.D. Certifications can be accredited.
quizSrc.definition: A. Certifications are issued by industry certification bodies.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following tools can be used to prepare for a certification exam?A. The domain domains and objectives in the exam blueprint.B. Summative assessments in Coursera preparatory course.C. Instructor-led or self-paced courses in the exam domains.
quizSrc.definition: A. The domain domains and objectives in the exam blueprint.  B. Summative assessments in Coursera preparatory course.  C. Instructor-led or self-paced courses in the exam domains.

quizSrc.term: Which of thefollowing tools can be used to prepare for a certification exam?A. The domain domains and objectives in the exam blueprint.B. Summative assessments in Coursera preparatory course.C. Instructor-led or self-paced courses in the exam domains.
quizSrc.definition: A. The domain domains and objectives in the exam blueprint.  B. Summative assessments in Coursera preparatory course.  C. Instructor-led or self-paced courses in the exam domains.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are included in an exam blueprint?A. Practice questionsB. The length of the examC. How to schedule your examD. Time and date of your exam
quizSrc.definition: B. The length of the exam

quizSrc.term: Upon successful completion of your exam, which of the following actions can you take to share your certification with employers and peers?A. Post your Accredible-issued badge on social platforms such as LinkedIn.B. Forward the email notification from Pearson VUE that you receive upon passing the exam to your employer.C. Share a screenshot from the end of the exam showing that you passed.D. Display your Coursera Professional Certificate on social platforms such as LinkedIn.
quizSrc.definition: A. Post your Accredible-issued badge on social platforms such as LinkedIn.

quizSrc.term: You have scheduled your exam at a Pearson VUE test center. Which of the following should you do before you leave for your appointment at the test center?A. Make sure you have your mobile phone to take photos of the exam room to provide to the proctor.B. Verify that you have run the speed test on the computer that you plan to take the exam on.C. Pack snacks and drinks to have during the exam.D. Check that you have the government-issued ID that you used during registration.
quizSrc.definition: D. Check that you have the government-issued ID that you used during registration.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following are included in the CertNexus Candidate Agreement?A. Instructions on how to schedule your examB. Domains and objectives covered in the examC. Expectations of personal conduct such as cheatingD. List of subject matter experts that contributed to the job task analysis
quizSrc.definition: C. Expectations of personal conduct such as cheating

quizSrc.term: Reviewing the exam blueprint prior to scheduling your exam will allow candidates to do which of the following?A. Practice the skills required to complete the tasks outlined in the objectives.B. Consider whether you possess the knowledge, skills, and abilities required to successfully pass the exam.C. Practice exam items that reflect the questions on the certification exam.D. Consider whether you have the required degree or licensure to successfully pass the exam.
quizSrc.definition: B. Consider whether you possess the knowledge, skills, and abilities required to successfully pass the exam.

quizSrc.term: Which of the following is an easy and accessible way to demonstrate your skills alongside your certification?A. Post the link to your Accredible badge on global vendor-neutral blogsB. Post a video on social media discussing the value of certificationsC. Post on social platforms about how proficient you are in the subject areaD. Post evidence of your accomplishments on your Accredible profile
quizSrc.definition: D. Post evidence of your accomplishments on your Accredible profile

quizSrc.term: (WEEK 1) Question 1 Is ethics a checklist? A. True B. False
quizSrc.definition: B. False

quizSrc.term: Question 2 What is moral responsibility? A. It corresponds to liability B. It means to be accountable for our actions and the effects of these actions C. It means to adopt a moral theory describing responsibility D. It is an ethical approach in professional life
quizSrc.definition: B. It means to be accountable for our actions and the effects of these actions

quizSrc.term: Question 3 Moral responsibility is based on: (Select multiple answers) A. ethical theories B. obligations and norms arising from moral considerations C. personal presuppositions D. moral duties
quizSrc.definition: B. obligations and norms arising from moral considerations D. moral duties

quizSrc.term: Question 4 Is Passive Responsibility a form of backward-looking responsibility? A. True B. False
quizSrc.definition: A. True

quizSrc.term: Question 5 Which are the elements that play a key role in assessing responsibility? (Select multiple answers) A. Accountability B. Morality C. Ethics D. Blameworthiness
quizSrc.definition: A. Accountability D. Blameworthiness

quizSrc.term: Question 6 What is foreseeability? A. The ability to predict the future B. To describe responsible action C. To have freedom of action D.To be able to know the consequences of action
quizSrc.definition: D. To be able to know the consequences of action

quizSrc.term: Question 7 Active responsibility means... (Select multiple answers) A. to attribute responsibility in a backward-looking way B. to prevent the negative effects of technology C. to causally contributing to the development of a technology D. to realize some positive consequences of technology
quizSrc.definition: B. to prevent the negative effects of technology D. to realize some positive consequences of technology

quizSrc.term: Question 8 Is Value Sensitive Design a form of active responsibility? A. True B. False
quizSrc.definition: A. True

quizSrc.term: (WEEK 2) Question 1 What is utilitarianism? (Select muliple answers). A. A type of consequentialism, where decisions and actions are evaluated as morally good or bad according to the consequences they bring about B. An ethical framework based on the utility principle C. A form of ethics based on duties D. A moral approach explaining the principle of utility
quizSrc.definition: A. A type of consequentialism, where decisions and actions are evaluated as morally good or bad according to the consequences they bring about B. An ethical framework based on the utility principle

quizSrc.term: Question 2 Is duty ethics a framework in which an action is considered morally right if it agrees with a certain moral rule? A. True B. False
quizSrc.definition: A. True

quizSrc.term: Question 3 What does it mean that a weapon system is autonomous? A. It means that it has moral capabilities B. It means that it is not independent from human supervision C. It means that it has navigation, exploration and attack capabilities and does not require continuous human supervision D. It means designing autonomous weapons to avoid negative consequences
quizSrc.definition: C. It means that it has navigation, exploration and attack capabilities and does not require continuous human supervision

quizSrc.term: Question 4 What is meaningful human control? (Select multiple answers) A. The type of control for which the human controller must have enough information and time to intervene on the autonomous systems B. A concept proposed in the last years as a necessary condition for the responsible employment of autonomous weapon systems C. A way to describe how autonomous systems work
quizSrc.definition: A. The type of control for which the human controller must have enough information and time to intervene on the autonomous systems B. A concept proposed in the last years as a necessary condition for the responsible employment of autonomous weapon systems

quizSrc.term: Question 5 Digital health and digital medicine have mainly four areas of application A. True B. False
quizSrc.definition: A. True

quizSrc.term: Question 6 To establish the sustainability of digital services, it is important... A. to measure all the consequences deriving from digital services B. to evaluate the involved stakeholders C. to consider both the numerical value of their environmental impact and their social value
quizSrc.definition: C. to consider both the numerical value of their environmental impact and their social value

quizSrc.term: Question 7 What is the goal of cybersecurity? A. To promote security breaches B. To guarantee the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of information C. To avoid the confidentiality of information D. To combat hackers
quizSrc.definition: B. To guarantee the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of information

quizSrc.term: (WEEK 3) Question 1 Automated Decision Systems (Select multiple answers) A. use today a traditional top-down approach B. have the ability to learn from experience C. process data about people and combine human and automated decision making
quizSrc.definition: B. have the ability to learn from experience C. process data about people and combine human and automated decision making

quizSrc.term: Question 2 Is classification a possible form of learning? A. True B. False
quizSrc.definition: A. True

quizSrc.term: Question 3 To say that Automated Decision Systems are black boxes means that: (Select multiple answers) A. their decisions can be explained B. they are designed according to the Explainable AI approach C. they are not transparent D. they hide their internal logic to the user
quizSrc.definition: C. they are not transparent D. they hide their internal logic to the user

quizSrc.term: Question 4 An algorithm is biased when: A. it is trained on a set of data containing biases B. it is designed to solve racial prejudices C. it lacks appropriate biases
quizSrc.definition: A. it is trained on a set of data containing biases

quizSrc.term: Question 5 Is Privacy related to the right to be left alone? A. True B. False
quizSrc.definition: A. True

quizSrc.term: Question 6 Privacy... (Select multiple answers) A. ...only protects people who have something to hide B. ...is not overrated C. ...is about intensive tracking and monitoring of behaviors D. ...is totally lost today
quizSrc.definition: B. ...is not overrated C. ...is about intensive tracking and monitoring of behaviors

quizSrc.term: Question 7 Privacy does not play an essential role for the diversity of relationships. A. False B. True
quizSrc.definition: A. False

quizSrc.term: Question 8 What is a panopticon? A. A digital tool to spy people B. A way of considering privacy as essential only to those who have something to hide C. A structure designed to serve as a prison D. A metaphor to describe the freedom of individuals
quizSrc.definition: C. A structure designed to serve as a prison

quizSrc.term: Question 9 The moralization of technologies is: (Select multiple answers) A. the deliberate development of technologies in order to shape moral action and moral decision-making B. the design of moral intelligent agents C. the attempt to moralize the material environment in which people operate D. the field of ethics devoted to the study of the consequences of technologies
quizSrc.definition: A. the deliberate development of technologies in order to shape moral action and moral decision-making C. the attempt to moralize the material environment in which people operate

quizSrc.term: Question 10 What are experimental technologies? A. technologies that need collaborative experimentation to be tested B. technologies with a limited operational experience C. technologies involving the experimentation on human subjects D. technologies requiring the involvement of experimentalists to be designed
quizSrc.definition: B. technologies with a limited operational experience

quizSrc.term: (WEEK 4) Question 1 Are codes of ethics and conduct related to professional ethics? A. True B. False
quizSrc.definition: A. True

quizSrc.term: Question 2 Professional codes... (Select multiple answers) A. ...describe computing professionals B. ...are formulated for a variety of reasons C. ...express the values of integrity, honesty, and avoid of conflict of interest D. ...try to use mathematical formulas to express the responsibilities of professionals
quizSrc.definition: B. ...are formulated for a variety of reasons C. ...express the values of integrity, honesty, and avoid of conflict of interest

quizSrc.term: Question 3 What is a socio-technical perspective in the ethics of AI? A. it is a technical approach to the solution of ethical issues B. it concerns the fact that ethical issues of AI can be solved both by humans and machines C. it means integrating technical solutions into broader ethical and social frameworks
quizSrc.definition: C. it means integrating technical solutions into broader ethical and social frameworks

quizSrc.term: Question 4 Ethics of AI... (Select multiple answers) A. ...requires a paradigm change B. ...involves different stakeholders C. ...has the goal of implementing machines with an ethics D. ...considers AI tools and techniques as dangerous
quizSrc.definition: A. ...requires a paradigm change B. ...involves different stakeholders
